69TH YEAR

Finlay, Mongiardo, Kirk Elected
DIU PROF APPOINTED
JuneWeek Committee Bittick, Griffith, Brickman Win S.C. Positions; Hopkins Geneticist
Ponders Boat Cruise, Frosh Lead Undergrad Participation With 75% Named Vice-Pres.
At New York State U.
Terminal Sr. Blast
June Week activities will begin
Tuesday, June 1, with the Port
Welcome's cruse up the Chesapeake Bay, and will climax in
on
Commencement exercises
June 8. A full range of events,
from the boat cruse to the senior
dinner, have been arranged by
John Dalton and his June Week
Committee.
A strip of tickets for the week's
events may be purchased by
seniors for $12 until May 10, and
for $15 afterward. The price for
all other students is $15. Tickets
may be purchased after April
from the June Week Committee:
John Dalton, Ron Coonin, Jerry
Ruark, Mike McGeorge, Jon Harlow, Steve Reynolds. Chip Giardina, Dick Bensinger, Bruce
Steinwald, Dick Hillman, and
John Glascock.

rowly beat out Bill Angrick, 10692. Al Guba was elected vice-president, and Bruce Ledig was
chosen secretary-treastu-er. Bill
Reinsch received an unusually
large amount of support, getting
157 votes. Also returned to office
was Bud Bozarth, while Dennis
In the battle for president of Clements will take the third seat
the class of '68, John Kirk nar- for next year's sophomores.

Over fifty percent of the
student body elected class officers
this week in elections that have
now produced two protests over
procedural matters. Technical
charges ensnare the S.C. presidential election and illegal petitioning befouls the junior class
elections. The decisions on the
disputes will be made Monday at
the Student Council meeting.

nod for vice-president, while Joe
Mulinare was elected secretarytreasurer. Student Council rereturned
presentatives
were
Sandy Cohn, Council secretary
this year, and Tony Romeo, with
Don Trump gaining election for
the first time.

In junior class elections, Peter
Finlay won the presidency by a
two-to-one margin, largest of
any candidate running for any
office. Bob Bittick, who was defeated two weeks ago in a bid for
the Student Council presidency,
was elected as Council representative. Other officers of the class
of '66 are: Sandy Kuehl, vicepresident; Rodger Searfoss, secretary-treasurer; and Jeff Griffith and John Brickman (associate editor of the News-Letter),
Student Council representatives.

New IBM System

of '67 was Jim Mongiardo, who is

Lee Andrews and the Hearts will
provide music throughout the
cruise and set-ups will be available. Individual tickets for the
trip will be $4 per couple.

Three years of study by the
Department of Operations Research at Hopkins has resulted
in the establishment of the new
computer-run book circulation
system in the library. Designed
by Ben Cartwright, the system
was instituted just two weeks
ago. Refinement will be made
whenever necessary to make the
method as efficient as possible.
Operations Research began
the study of the old depart-

mental libraries and the manual
checkout system on instructions
from the University. With the
new composite library being
constructed. the old system was
deemed impossible to maintain,
so the group designed the new
procedure.
According to assistant librarian George Walton, "The
new system is not desgined to
levy fines but to let the stu(Continued on Page 2)

Speech Analysis

Seniors will meet in the Clipper Room in Shriver June 2 to
elect permanent class officers.
Free beer will be served at the
gathering.
The annual senior picnic will
be held on June 3 at the Glen
Dale Golf Club from 12:00 to
9:00 p.m. A fast band, the
Admirals, will entertain the
seniors, who will feast on a bull
roast and beer. The picnic will
cost $8 per couple.
A sixteen-piece slow dance
band, the King Guard Orchestra,
will highlight the Prom on Sunday evening, June 6, at the Valley Country Club. There will be
an open bar all night. Tickets for
this event will also be $8 per
couple.
The last social event for the
class of 1965 will be the senior
banquet at the Sheraton Belvedere Hotel. A cocktail hour is
set for 6:30, with dinner to follow. The dinner speaker is yet to
be named.
Commencement ceremonies will
bring the week to an end, beginning at 9:30 A.M. Tuesday,
June 8. in the Keyser Quadrangle.

Alpha Epsilon Delta
The International premedical honorary fraternity, AED,
is considering requests for
membership. Interested sophomores and juniors drop a card
with your name, class, average, and interests in Box 973.
Deadline is April 23

Lodge Defends Vietnam Aid

Henry Cabot Lodge, former
United States Ambassador to
South Vietnam, said that the
people of that nation must be
aided and trained in combating
the "subversion-terrorism" of
the Viet Cong.
Speaking in Shriver Hall on
Friday, April 9, Mr. Lodge was
the final guest in the Views on
Foreign Policy lecture series.
According to Mr. Lodge, Vietnam is important to the West
because its geographical position makes it a vital area in
Southeast Asia. Also, that country has long played a part in
the political development of the
Far East.
Lodge cited the war in Vietnam as one more event in a long
series of Communist aggressions
and as an open encounter with
the "wars of revolution" which
are fundamental to Communist
doctrine. He stated that North
Vietnam is backed by the Chinese, and that American efforts
in the South will probably answer the question of whether
the Chinese Communists can be
contained on the Asian mainland. He said that a Communist
success in Vietnam would lead
the Soviet Union to take a more
"bellicose" view toward the West.
Lodge said that our efforts in
Vietnam have not been in vain.
They have resulted in an able
organization and a trained military. American social aid has
provided hospitals, schools, and

information to the people.
Mr. Lodge advocated continuation of the civil and military
plans already laid down by the
Administration. He maintained
that Vietnam is not a local war,
and that weapons, supplies, and
directions come to the Viet Cong
from the North.
He stated that the question as
to ways in which a settlement
can be reached has not seemed
to have been considered in Communist countries. Lodge said
that. "Peaceful words without
peaceful behavior are misleading and dangerous."
In explaining the nature of
the war, Lodge related that Vietnam has seen the advent of a
new fighting man—the terrorist.
He is supposedly part of a highly
organized, efficiently trained, and
well directed association. The

HENRY CABOT LODGE

former ambassador said that
terrorism is the life supply of
the Viet Cong.
Mr. Lodge said that, although
our help opposes the traditions
of the Vietnamese, we must be
patient. He quoted Mao Tse
Tung's statement, "Politics is
war without bloodshed, and thus
war is politics with bloodshed."
Lodge stated that there is no
quick or simple or strictly military solution to the Vietnam
crisis, and that the greatest
single danger to free society is
terrorism and subversion. He
said, "Stalemate is much better
than a defeat."
In answering a question on
whether "calm" can be restored
to the area by our present methods, Lodge replied that "punitive actions" will make North
Vietnam see that their aggression is impractical and that
economic aid and anti-terrorist
measures in the South will better
the American position.
Following his speech. Mr.
Lodge was the guest of the
Young Republicans at a buffet
held in the Great Hall in Levering. Attending were students
from Hopkins, Goucher, and
other colleges in the area. In a
frank, off-the-record discussion,
the former ambassador answered
a barrage of questions on American foreign policy in Southeast
Asia, providing a valuable insight
into the current position of the
United States in world affairs.

Dr. H. Bentley Glass, professor
of biology at JIM. has been appointed academic vice president
State University of New York at
Stony Brook, Long Island.

T h e internationally - known
geneticist is one of the country's
top biologists and has been associated with Hopkins since 1947.
Dr. Glass will officially assume
his new position on September 1.
As vice president. Dr. Glass will
be the principal academic officer and will aid in supervising
the faculty's instruction and research.
Stony Brok has recently been
chosen to be the center for studies in marine biology for the New
York State University system.
It is initiating an extensive program in the earth, marine, and
space sciences.
Dr. Glass is the author of several books, including Forerunners of Darwin and Science and
Liberal Education. Hz! has also
written more than 200 scientific,
professional, and general articles.
Dr. Glass has served as editor
of the Quarterly Review of Bi9Iogy, as president of the American Society of Naturalists, and
as a member of the board of
directors of the American A.ssociation for the Advancement of
Science.

Student Council
Decides Nothing
A motion establishing a
"Whereabouts Bulletin Board" in
the new library passed by the
Student Council in its regular
Monday night meeting this week.
Representative Matt Liang in
proposing the motion noted that
it was almost impossible to locate anyone in the library. A
bulletin board near the circulation desk would allow students
to post information as to where
they could be found. He reported that the library administration was amenable to .this
proposal,
The Council expressed some
concern about Hank Ballard's
failure to show at the Big Weekend. The IFC apparently is in
danger of losing $1,500 in the
_affair.
Contract Problems
IFC Representative Jon Shanser commented, "I don't think
any undergraduate in this school
ought to be able to sign a contract of this sort."However, the
Council decided nothing finally
on this issue.
Freshman Representative Bud
Bozarth stated that a lot of
in-town students were complaining about parking space. John
Sanborn of the Council's traffic

NEWS-LETTER

Piano Soloist Radnytsky
Gives Second Jill Recital
For the second time this year,
Hopkins will host Roman Rudmytsky, the 22 year old American
piano virtuoso. The Class of 1966,
under the Woodrow Wilson Program, will present Rudnytsky in
a piano recital. Sunday evening

Orientation
Any student vvha wants to
work on the Orientation Committee next fall should pick
up an application at the Admissions Office in Shriver
Hall. Questions may be sent
to Bob O'Connor. Box 2045.

at 8:30 p.m. in Shriver Hall. Admission is free.
Rudnytsky is a senior scholarship student, studying under Hosins. Lhevinne at Julliard School
of Music in New York City. He is
in the masterclass of Egon Petri
and Wilhelm Kempff, and the
winner of over 20 state and
national competitions including
the International Bach Festival,
the Griffith Music Foundation
Award, arid the National Piano
Teacher's Guild Gold Medal. He
has been a soloist with civic and
state orchestras throughout the
country and in Canada.

Computerized Filing System Installed
(Continued from Page 1)
dents know where the books are.
It will make the collection more
useful to the student body."
Each student and faculty
member will be issued a numbered card at the beginning of
each year. The computer has in
its memory the name of each
person and his number. At the
checkout desk a microfilm picture will be taken of each person's card and the books he
checks out. A camera is installed
under the checkout desk for this
purpose. Eventually, to make the'
systm more efficient, a portable
camera will be carried around
to charge out books to faculty
studies.
A predated due date sticker is
then placed on the outside of the
book.
The developed microfilm is immediately sent to a key punch
operator who records on an IBM
card the book call number of all
books handled. The computer
then prints out a list of books
in circulation. The staff will then
compose a list of "who has which
book," so that books checked out
may be located.
When the book is returned.
another photo is taken and the
date sticker is removed. The key
punch operator will discharge
the book, and the computer will

eliminate it from the next day's
print out list. The computer will
also be used to print overdue
notices.
The new system is not expected to cost more than the
previous manual and departmental procedures. The computers are not only for the li-

concerning interdepartmental athletics.
This bulletin board space
has been arranged by the
Graduate Activities Committee (GAC) in cooperation with the library staff.
Mr. John Berthel, head librarian, has tentatively assigned 113 of the space on
each of 4 bulletin boards in
the new library to graduate
activities. GAC hopes that

Lord Of The Flies
Ho! Ho! The Hoppies really mocked themselves
on Wednesday night. Though the Intermok rally proved
abortive, the audience comprised mainly of infantile
freshman dorm inhabitants, made a real show of themselves. Loud childishness and threats of violence were
featured, with a supporting cast long on idiocy as it
was short on humor'. We were surprised that INTERMOK
fell, but it did not fail. In lieu of the expected speakers,
the HAPPENING of that evening was spontaneous an,
and its message had to do with the idiocy of those who
told a story they did not understand. 1NTERMOK was
revived on its potential death bed who intended to insure
its fall.

Princess In The Making
We are given to wonder at the abundance of cultural and political presentations at the Homewood this
spring. We wonder whether the occasions are just petals
of a premature and temporary flower, and whether
we've not delighted in glamour beyond our means.
The importation of Francis Hinsley from Cambridge, the weekly and hi-weekly consultation and verbal
play with the boys from Washington, rubbing shoulders
with Presidents, sheiks and fezzes, climaxing in the
fruition of Intermok, bespeak a wondrous new activity
of Hopkins.
Leaving no piece unturned, The YMCA has invited
Hugh Hefner to tell his story; no doubt to clue us in
on how to handle a moral situation in the makings of a
prince and, who knows, maybe a princess or two.
It's now "the thing" to be a Hoppie. 1500 fellows
become einderelias of a cultured world if only by association. We hope the dance won't end before our time
and that if the shoe fits, we have the poise to polish it.

Students of Johns Hopkins
were presented with the worst
social event of recent years this
past, Saturday evening. The "Big
Weekend" dance, or so it was
called, resembled the poorest of
the movie-mixers. Hank Ballard
never showed his face; the backup group was missing its seventh
member, and took break so long
that it appeared to have two engagements that evening. There
was no slow dance music to be
had, even at 1230 A.M.

fruleace

For five dollars we received
two hours of -music", exorbitant
food and parking prices, and an
extremely poor band. I call for
the 1PC to give a 50% rebate to
ticket-buyers, and to turn organization of the dance over to a
group of more efficient, responsible individuals; an ad hoc committee would be a suggestion.

Lastly, I would suggest that
even should the dance be a financial failure, ticket purchasers
are entitled to what they have
paid for. Certainly we won't want
to go to the dances next year
For students bringing their with this sort of a track record.
girls down for a big college weekRobert R. Smith
end, Johns Hopkins now seems
worse than the local country high
No Snapshots
school at its "freshman fling."
Persistent rumors that Hank
Ballard was called up and told
not to show up have been circulating, as they did two years ago
when the Doug Clark Combo
didn't show up. It seems to me
that any efficient organizing body
would take out insurance on the
fact that the bands will show up,
in order to provide for a rebate
to students.

To the Editors:
Some four weeks ago I sent
a letter to the office of Mr. Robert P. Bilgrave, Director of Admissions for Johns Hopkins, in
which I suggested that the University should no longer require
applicants to the undergraduate
school to affix photographs to
their applications, in order to give
greater assurance that no racial

discrimination is practiced in the
University's admissions policy. I
gave what seemed to me a workable alternative plan by which
the purpose served by the photographs would be otherwise provided for, and made one or two
other proposals as well. I requested a reply from Mr. Bilgraves' office.
Two weeks later I went to the
Admissions Office to find out
why I had got no answer. A
gentleman there informed me
that my letter was "on his desk",
and that he would answer it as
soon as he was through with
the business of selecting the new
freshman class.
It is now two weeks after that.
Maybe Mr. Bilgrave'c colleagues
have in fact been so busy for
four solid weeks that they have
found no time to answer my
letter: but I think that their
attitude is clear, and is not theirs
alone: be the occasion student
outrage at the evil lies of McGeorge Bundy, or student protest
at racial discrimination, students
are disruptive, out of order, and
not to be heard.

Ugly, Kan! Student Council
Sixteen candidates are currently vying for the title of "Ugliest
Man on Campus." The winner
will receive a plaque from APO
at the halftime of the Homecoming lacrosse against Navy game
on May 8.
Votes are cast by depositing
pennies, nickles, dimes, or quarters in the U.M.O.C. voting
machine. Votes increase with the
amount of the donation, as do
the gyrations of the unusually
constructed machine. The money
obtained will be used to support
the education of a Chinese youth,
Wai Chon.
The voting machine will remain in Levering through Saturday, and will then be returned
to the dormitory snack bar until
the end of the contest on Friday,
April 23. Tabulated scores of the
individual candidates are being
kept hidden to maintain a high
level of suspense.

Frosh Debaters Make Debate Council's Year
At the Dickinson College Novice Debate Tournament last Saturday. four freshmen won for
the Hopkins council, the biggest
debate victory of the year. Individually and collectively, the
team members took a total of
four awards.
The four man team of George
Miller, Julian Spirer, Bob Scheible. and Terry Leveck received
third place overall in the tournament. The negative team, Miller and Spirer, won all four of

Seniors will meet in the Clipper Room in Shriver June 2 to
elect permanent class officers.
Free beer will be served at the
gathering.
The annual senior picnic will
be held on June 3 at the Glen
Dale Golf Club from 12:00 to
9:00 p.m. A fast band, the
Admirals, will entertain the
seniors, who will feast on a bull
roast and beer. The picnic will
cost $8 per couple.
A sixteen-piece slow dance
band, the King Guard Orchestra,
will highlight the Prom on Sunday evening, June 6, at the Valley Country Club. There will be
an open bar all night. Tickets for
this event will also be $8 per
couple.
The last social event for the
class of 1965 will be the senior
banquet at the Sheraton Belvedere Hotel. A cocktail hour is
set for 6:30, with dinner to follow. The dinner speaker is yet to
be named.
Commencement ceremonies will
bring the week to an end, beginning at 9:30 A.M. Tuesday,
June 8. in the Keyser Quadrangle.

The International premedical honorary fraternity, AED,

Lodge Defends Vietnam Aid

Henry Cabot Lodge, former
United States Ambassador to
South Vietnam, said that the
people of that nation must be
aided and trained in combating
the "subversion-terrorism" of
the Viet Cong.
Speaking in Shriver Hall on
Friday, April 9, Mr. Lodge was
the final guest in the Views on
Foreign Policy lecture series.
According to Mr. Lodge, Vietnam is important to the West
because its geographical position makes it a vital area in
Southeast Asia. Also, that country has long played a part in
the political development of the
Far East.
Lodge cited the war in Vietnam as one more event in a long
series of Communist aggressions
and as an open encounter with
the "wars of revolution" which
are fundamental to Communist
doctrine. He stated that North
Vietnam is backed by the Chinese, and that American efforts
in the South will probably answer the question of whether
the Chinese Communists can be
contained on the Asian mainland. He said that a Communist
success in Vietnam would lead
the Soviet Union to take a more
"bellicose" view toward the West.
Lodge said that our efforts in
Vietnam have not been in vain.
They have resulted in an able
organization and a trained military. American social aid has
provided hospitals, schools, and

information to the people.
Mr. Lodge advocated continuation of the civil and military
plans already laid down by the
Administration. He maintained
that Vietnam is not a local war,
and that weapons, supplies, and
directions come to the Viet Cong
from the North.
He stated that the question as
to ways in which a settlement
can be reached has not seemed
to have been considered in Communist countries. Lodge said
that. "Peaceful words without
peaceful behavior are misleading and dangerous."
In explaining the nature of
the war, Lodge related that Vietnam has seen the advent of a
new fighting man—the terrorist.
He is supposedly part of a highly
organized, efficiently trained, and
well directed association. The

HENRY CABOT LODGE

former ambassador said that
terrorism is the life supply of
the Viet Cong.
Mr. Lodge said that, although
our help opposes the traditions
of the Vietnamese, we must be
patient. He quoted Mao Tse
Tung's statement, "Politics is
war without bloodshed, and thus
war is politics with bloodshed."
Lodge stated that there is no
quick or simple or strictly military solution to the Vietnam
crisis, and that the greatest
single danger to free society is
terrorism and subversion. He
said, "Stalemate is much better
than a defeat."
In answering a question on
whether "calm" can be restored
to the area by our present methods, Lodge replied that "punitive actions" will make North
Vietnam see that their aggression is impractical and that
economic aid and anti-terrorist
measures in the South will better
the American position.
Following his speech. Mr.
Lodge was the guest of the
Young Republicans at a buffet
held in the Great Hall in Levering. Attending were students
from Hopkins, Goucher, and
other colleges in the area. In a
frank, off-the-record discussion,
the former ambassador answered
a barrage of questions on American foreign policy in Southeast
Asia, providing a valuable insight
into the current position of the
United States in world affairs.

Dr. H. Bentley Glass, professor
of biology at JIM. has been appointed academic vice president
State University of New York at
Stony Brook, Long Island.

T h e internationally - known
geneticist is one of the country's
top biologists and has been associated with Hopkins since 1947.
Dr. Glass will officially assume
his new position on September 1.
As vice president. Dr. Glass will
be the principal academic officer and will aid in supervising
the faculty's instruction and research.
Stony Brok has recently been
chosen to be the center for studies in marine biology for the New
York State University system.
It is initiating an extensive program in the earth, marine, and
space sciences.
Dr. Glass is the author of several books, including Forerunners of Darwin and Science and
Liberal Education. Hz! has also
written more than 200 scientific,
professional, and general articles.
Dr. Glass has served as editor
of the Quarterly Review of Bi9Iogy, as president of the American Society of Naturalists, and
as a member of the board of
directors of the American A.ssociation for the Advancement of
Science.

Student Council
Decides Nothing
A motion establishing a
"Whereabouts Bulletin Board" in
the new library passed by the
Student Council in its regular
Monday night meeting this week.
Representative Matt Liang in
proposing the motion noted that
it was almost impossible to locate anyone in the library. A
bulletin board near the circulation desk would allow students
to post information as to where
they could be found. He reported that the library administration was amenable to .this
proposal,
The Council expressed some
concern about Hank Ballard's
failure to show at the Big Weekend. The IFC apparently is in
danger of losing $1,500 in the
_affair.

on this issue.

Each student and faculty
member will be issued a numbered card at the beginning of
each year. The computer has in
its memory the name of each
person and his number. At the
checkout desk a microfilm picture will be taken of each person's card and the books he
checks out. A camera is installed
under the checkout desk for this
purpose. Eventually, to make the'
systm more efficient, a portable
camera will be carried around
to charge out books to faculty
studies.
A predated due date sticker is
then placed on the outside of the
book.
The developed microfilm is immediately sent to a key punch
operator who records on an IBM
card the book call number of all
books handled. The computer
then prints out a list of books
in circulation. The staff will then
compose a list of "who has which
book," so that books checked out
may be located.
When the book is returned.
another photo is taken and the
date sticker is removed. The key
punch operator will discharge
the book, and the computer will

eliminate it from the next day's
print out list. The computer will
also be used to print overdue
notices.
The new system is not expected to cost more than the
previous manual and departmental procedures. The computers are not only for the li-

Lord Of The Flies
Ho! Ho! The Hoppies really mocked themselves
on Wednesday night. Though the Intermok rally proved
abortive, the audience comprised mainly of infantile
freshman dorm inhabitants, made a real show of themselves. Loud childishness and threats of violence were
featured, with a supporting cast long on idiocy as it
was short on humor'. We were surprised that INTERMOK
fell, but it did not fail. In lieu of the expected speakers,
the HAPPENING of that evening was spontaneous an,
and its message had to do with the idiocy of those who
told a story they did not understand. 1NTERMOK was
revived on its potential death bed who intended to insure
its fall.

Princess In The Making
We are given to wonder at the abundance of cultural and political presentations at the Homewood this
spring. We wonder whether the occasions are just petals
of a premature and temporary flower, and whether
we've not delighted in glamour beyond our means.
The importation of Francis Hinsley from Cambridge, the weekly and hi-weekly consultation and verbal
play with the boys from Washington, rubbing shoulders
with Presidents, sheiks and fezzes, climaxing in the
fruition of Intermok, bespeak a wondrous new activity
of Hopkins.
Leaving no piece unturned, The YMCA has invited
Hugh Hefner to tell his story; no doubt to clue us in
on how to handle a moral situation in the makings of a
prince and, who knows, maybe a princess or two.
It's now "the thing" to be a Hoppie. 1500 fellows
become einderelias of a cultured world if only by association. We hope the dance won't end before our time
and that if the shoe fits, we have the poise to polish it.

Students of Johns Hopkins
were presented with the worst
social event of recent years this
past, Saturday evening. The "Big
Weekend" dance, or so it was
called, resembled the poorest of
the movie-mixers. Hank Ballard
never showed his face; the backup group was missing its seventh
member, and took break so long
that it appeared to have two engagements that evening. There
was no slow dance music to be
had, even at 1230 A.M.

fruleace

For five dollars we received
two hours of -music", exorbitant
food and parking prices, and an
extremely poor band. I call for
the 1PC to give a 50% rebate to
ticket-buyers, and to turn organization of the dance over to a
group of more efficient, responsible individuals; an ad hoc committee would be a suggestion.

Lastly, I would suggest that
even should the dance be a financial failure, ticket purchasers
are entitled to what they have
paid for. Certainly we won't want
to go to the dances next year
For students bringing their with this sort of a track record.
girls down for a big college weekRobert R. Smith
end, Johns Hopkins now seems
worse than the local country high
No Snapshots
school at its "freshman fling."
Persistent rumors that Hank
Ballard was called up and told
not to show up have been circulating, as they did two years ago
when the Doug Clark Combo
didn't show up. It seems to me
that any efficient organizing body
would take out insurance on the
fact that the bands will show up,
in order to provide for a rebate
to students.

To the Editors:
Some four weeks ago I sent
a letter to the office of Mr. Robert P. Bilgrave, Director of Admissions for Johns Hopkins, in
which I suggested that the University should no longer require
applicants to the undergraduate
school to affix photographs to
their applications, in order to give
greater assurance that no racial

discrimination is practiced in the
University's admissions policy. I
gave what seemed to me a workable alternative plan by which
the purpose served by the photographs would be otherwise provided for, and made one or two
other proposals as well. I requested a reply from Mr. Bilgraves' office.
Two weeks later I went to the
Admissions Office to find out
why I had got no answer. A
gentleman there informed me
that my letter was "on his desk",
and that he would answer it as
soon as he was through with
the business of selecting the new
freshman class.
It is now two weeks after that.
Maybe Mr. Bilgrave'c colleagues
have in fact been so busy for
four solid weeks that they have
found no time to answer my
letter: but I think that their
attitude is clear, and is not theirs
alone: be the occasion student
outrage at the evil lies of McGeorge Bundy, or student protest
at racial discrimination, students
are disruptive, out of order, and
not to be heard.

Ugly, Kan! Student Council
Sixteen candidates are currently vying for the title of "Ugliest
Man on Campus." The winner
will receive a plaque from APO
at the halftime of the Homecoming lacrosse against Navy game
on May 8.
Votes are cast by depositing
pennies, nickles, dimes, or quarters in the U.M.O.C. voting
machine. Votes increase with the
amount of the donation, as do
the gyrations of the unusually
constructed machine. The money
obtained will be used to support
the education of a Chinese youth,
Wai Chon.
The voting machine will remain in Levering through Saturday, and will then be returned
to the dormitory snack bar until
the end of the contest on Friday,
April 23. Tabulated scores of the
individual candidates are being
kept hidden to maintain a high
level of suspense.

"This book combines the
vision and hardheaded,
,practical touch of its author,
one of the ablest new figures
in public life of our generation. It is a book to give
courage and hope to the
anxious and fearful, and to
confirm the faith of those
who see what a great future
lies before mankind. If
Sargent Shriver's ringing
words could be read by millions — as I hope it will be —
it would advance the cause
of peace and tell Americans
more about their true selves
than any book I have seen
in many a year. It is a distinguished and thoughtful
book by a shining personality."
